page.title: 12RELIGION IN OVERTON
page.content: There is evidence of a church in Overton as far back as Saxon times.The present building,with its typical Norman doorway,dates largely from @1140 with additions in 1771.The church was a chapelry of the Benedictine Priory at Lancaster,and was served by the monks from 1068 to 1387.The various incumbents have lived in the village since the first parsonage was Glebe Farm on Main Street.The village is traditionally Anglican,but there is a more recent Roman Catholic church,St. BernardÂ£s,built in the 1960Â£s,to serve a growing Catholic community.In both villages,religion is predominantly the concern of the elders of the community with the exception of the R.C.group, which is mainly from the younger age group.
